item.title: Old Fashioned
item.description:
Some people will argue an Old Fashioned must be made with a sugar cube. Those people haven’t tried it with burnt sugar syrup.
  • 2 oz rye whiskey
  • ¾ oz burnt sugar syrup
  • 2 dashes Angostura bitters
  • 2 dashes orange bitters
  • orange twist
Add ice to a rocks glass. Add both bitters, then the whiskey and burnt sugar syrup. The syrup will sink to the bottom, so give it a quick stir to mix.

Cut a think slice of orange peel. Express the oils over the drink, then rub it around the rim of the glass and place it in the drink.

item.title: Daiquiri
item.description:
• 2 oz white rum
  • ¾ oz lime juice
  • ¾ oz simple syrup
Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with plenty of ice. Shake well and strain into a coupe glass.

item.title: Manhattan
item.description:
• 2 oz rye whiskey
  • 1 oz sweet vermouth
  • 2 dashes Angostura bitters
Combine in a shaker with ice. Stir, then strain into a coupe glass.

Garnish with a Maraschino cherry.

item.title: Martini
item.description:
Everyone has an opinion about martinis. I’ll spare you mine, and just give you my recipe. Trust me.

I often use a blanc vermouth instead of the traditional dry, but it’s delicious with either. Any type of gin works in a martini, but I prefer a sweeter style.

  • 2¼ oz genever gin
  • ¾ oz dry vermouth
Add to cocktail shaker with plenty of ice. Stir well, then strain into a martini glass.

Garnish with a lemon twist.

item.title: Sidecar
item.description:
The simple syrup isn’t traditional, but that’s how I learned it, and I like the touch of additional sweetness.
  • 2 oz Cognac
  • ¾ oz orange liqueur
  • ¾ oz lemon juice
  • ¼ oz simple syrup
  • orange twist, discarded
Shake vigorously with ice. Strain into a coupe glass.

Express the oils from an orange twist over the drink, then discard the peel.
